body:
I have to ask this question unfortunately.....
Why has the Guardian been a cheerleader for Theresa Mayhem?
Is it because she is a woman or has the Guardian gone right-wing?
Her claims and no debate about Brexit (she called this election for)
have gone unchallenged.

We've had stronger opposition from the editor of
the Evening Standard who has been headlining / frontpage about all
the claims on Brexit from his own Tory party on...

Immigration cap of tens of thousands:


Yesterday's frontpage...
" Migration: The question Tories won't answer.
The Evening standard has challenged every member of the cabinet to name an industry or sector
that they believed should take fewer overseas workers....
None identified a business or sector that should recruit fewer foreign staff....."
Silence of the Ministers:
Philip Hammond, Chancellor
Boris Johnson, Foreign
David Davis, Brexit
Amber Rudd, Home office
Jeremy Hunt, Health
Michael Fallon, Defence
Andrea Leadsom, Environment
Chris Grayling, Transport
Damian Green, Pensions
Sajid Javid, Local government
Justine Greening, Education
Karen Bradley, Culture

"None can say where migrants cuts will fall"

The claim that "No Brexit deal being better" was torn to pieces
as it doesn't stand up to scrutiny for example the £ has already droped 15%-20%
making most of us poorer.
Not knowing the cost of Brexit or of a "No deal" without a government impact assesment
to families and businesses...but how can Theresa Mayhem claim to know what a Bad deal is....

And on the Tory campaign that many so-called journalists including in the Guardian told
us was the Maybot's brilliant strategy of parking on Labour's lawn...


Evening standard comment:
"The Conservative campaign has meandered from an abortive attempt to launch a personality cult
around Mrs May to the self-inflicted wound of the most disastrous manifesto in recent history and,
after the atrocity in Manchester, shrill attacks on Mr Corbyn’s appeasement of terrorism.
"

Meanwhile the Guardian has headlines about Jeremy Corbyn minor
lapse on child care costs which were already detailed in the same
BBC R4 an hour earlier by a member of the shadow cabinet on the
Today programme. So the BBC already had the costs on record.

responses.body:
Yes, reading this from NYC (I'm not sure whether I'm glad to be away for the campaign but I'm back to vote) I found it amazing when I clicked on this morning and saw the headline about childcare figures. Jesus Christ, he's probably exhausted - anyone can forget a figure. The Tories haven't produced any.

I find it extraordinary that the Guardian has to pick as many holes as it can - at this stage it should be working hard to get Labour as many votes as possible. My sense, from the extracts I saw, was that the so-called debate was a car crash for Mayhem - but that's not the impression you get from reading the Guardian.

I'm not sure why it would be The Guardians job to proselytise to the extent of skewed reporting ...... Whilst all papers take a view,they're hardly likely to ignore all the gaffes that are reported everywhere else,are they?

From watching the whole May/Corbyn programme as a non Tory/non labour supporter, I saw s draw. Both better than previously, both suffering hits at different points
Nothing game changing in it

As for the "he just forgot a number" spiel do many are trotting out, I don't get this for two reasons
1) if it were May who'd not known the number, she'd have rightly been held up for it

2) these are the numbers in *his* manifesto. He should know then, not as s trick of memory, but because he was involved in working them out/drawing the whole thing together,and as such has been living and breathing the detail of his manifesto since they started work on it. He should know it like he knows his name - to not do so makes him look uninformed about his own proposals, which is not a good luck for an aspiring Prime Minister
May does not need to know any figures; there are hardly any in the Tory election plan drawn up on the back of a fag packet.

Jeremy's "Woman's Hour" interview was the first time he lost his increasingly sure-footing in this campaign - his first response? To apologise to his supporters for letting them down! Could you ever imagine May or any of the other arrogant narcissists from the Nasty Party displaying the same grace, humility and sense of service to their supporters?

body:
Theresa May's masters must know by now that the puppet they chosed was the wrong one . That is to be understood of course as in the post referendum chaos created by golden boy Cameron decisions had to be taken fast. Andrea Leadsom was fastly discarded as her Christian/right wing Consevratism can strangelly enough be bothersome to the "pro buisness" community responsible for taking the decisions .
Far right wing as well as the far left could sometimes be less flexible on buisness avancement (for different reasons of course), certainly less then centre right/centre left who has been accommodating corporations demandes with an admirable zeal and devotion.
Theresa May must have looked the perfect choice with the Thatcher undertones and typically British cold and from far dignified demeanor, but time was probably too short to check on her media credentials so none was aware of her misfortunate lack of charisma and wooden speach.
But there is a backlash payment for being too greedy and fast. Instead of giving the loyal media the time to finish with Corbyn who after two years of permenent warfare was in definite need of hiatus they rushed GE elections as May rather honestly admited would free her hands to pass number of reforms of which the British voters got the taste with the unfortunate manifesto. Programs that would have freed millions of homes for the real estate market, further pushed NHS in private hands etc all very exiting for big buisness.
The problem as seen as from today is that the news media is not the only manner to receive or give information and Labour has made rather good use of the social media lately, no doubt inspired by the campaign on Sanders whose downfall came from the endless tarnishing from the liberal newsvenues such as NYT, but rise and bloom was entirelly played on the social medias.
So instead of nice and cosy GE with Theresa May assured gain, UK has a surprising rise from the ashes for Labour with Corbyn on the wheel.
I do not know how the elections will end as lets not forget that May advance is very serious, but
if Corbyn win it will be a huge shock for the Tory donors, aka the pro buisness comunity aka corporations who has been betting on the wrong horse many times both geographically and historiaclly, but never experienced yet one of the strongest economies in the world being out of their full control. Brexit game over, UK was considered to be back in the tender mother care of US after years of straying with EU with the kind help of Murdoch and Dacre, but a Labour governément might actually insist on the "strange" idea of both financial and political independence(slight) from both EU and US which is basically unheard of.
If Corbyn wins, he will have to give in somewhere as he has no any chance to stay in power if the media go full strenght after him and missrepresent any of the governement acts for the following years. But if wisely adviced he might arive to pass reforms that will stop the further degradation of working/middle class. It is a historical moment and a very interesting one. The game has been ridged for as long as humanity exist, but sometimes the masses strike back and gain teritories considered long lost. I hope that this will be one of this moments as the situation in UK is becoming unbearable for any normal person and any change for better should be more then welcome.

body: Claire, your write-up of the Woman's Hour interview says that Corbyn called the abuse towards the interviewer "unacceptable," and your hyperlink on the word doesn't add anything more than that - it just goes to the summary article on Corbyn's "mixed day". "Unacceptable" mischaracterises the strength of his rebuttal and also prevents us from hearing in full what was an important statement - and also one which demonstrates a clear contrast between Corbyn's maturity of approach and Theresa May's approach yesterday. It would surely make more sense for the hyperlink to go to a transcript of Corbyn's actual statement?

responses.body: Can we also mention that she has a picture of Theresa May in her Twitter banner? She's an obvious partisan who was out to get him. Shameful for the BBC.
As far as the media are concerned, when it comes to Theresa, it's "May the false be with you."

Good morning - the hyperlink was more to give the context of the story and the comment, rather than to provide a transcript, but I'm happy to include the full remarks. I'll do a fresh post shortly to run them in full.
Now that's good service!
Full comments here now.

Thank you - I appreciate that, and as davidabsalom says, it's good service! At the risk of sounding pernickety, though, it looks as if what you have included doesn't include his full statement. I mention it just because I think it's an important point.

This is another part of what he said (it was reported on the Guardian livefeed yesterday (17.31)):

"It is totally and absolutely, completely unacceptable for anyone to throw abuse at anyone else. Journalists do ask difficult questions and journalists do do a job that does require asking difficult questions sometimes in difficult circumstances.
If you don’t like what a reporter says or asks me, or anybody else, understand the question they’re asking. We will all do our best to answer those questions, but under no circumstances whatsoever should anyone throw personal abuse at anyone else, because they are doing the job that they have been employed to do and I will not tolerate it under any circumstances."

Also:

"There isn’t such a thing as being unfair to politicians. If you put yourself up for elected office in public life you are subject to permanent scrutiny.
I never get upset by these things. Never be so high and mighty that you can’t listen to everybody else and make sure that you understand the motives of the majority of our people and the kind of society that we want to live in."
Thanks for posting this. Yet another demonstration - if more were needed - of why we need Jeremy Corbyn in number 10

body:
I wish someone would remind TM what she said as home secretary. Imagine if we didn't have a biased press? Imagine if instead of hounding Corbyn and other Labour MP's about what they said or didn't say 30 years ago the press concentrated on what May said just last year:

Security

We would still have our first-rate security and intelligence agencies. We would still share intelligence about terrorism and crime with our European allies, and they would do the same with us.

But that does not mean we would be as safe as if we remain. Outside the EU, for example, we would have no access to the European Arrest Warrant, which has allowed us to extradite more than 5,000 people from Britain to Europe in the last 5 years, and bring 675 suspected or convicted wanted individuals to Britain to face justice. It has been used to get terror suspects out of the country and bring terrorists back here to face justice. In 2005, Hussain Osman - who tried to blow up the London Underground on 21/7 - was extradited from Italy using the Arrest Warrant in just 56 days. Before the Arrest Warrant existed, it took 10 long years to extradite Rachid Ramda, another terrorist, from Britain to France.

There are other advantages too. Take the passenger name records directive. This will give law enforcement agencies access to information about the movements of terrorists, organised criminals and victims of trafficking on flights between European countries and from all other countries to the EU. this agreement will make us all safer. But it also shows 2 advantages of remaining inside the EU. First, without the kind of institutional framework offered by the European Union, a complex agreement like this could not have been struck across the whole continent, because bilateral deals between every single member state would have been impossible to reach....

So my judgement, as Home Secretary, is that remaining a member of the European Union means we will be more secure from crime and terrorism.

But now I want to turn to the other challenges we face in the coming decades: trade and the economy.
The headline facts of Britain’s trade with Europe are clear. The EU is a single market of more than 500 million people, representing an economy of almost £11 trillion and a quarter of the world’s GDP. 44% of our goods and services exports go to the EU, compared to 5% to India and China. We have a trade surplus in services with the rest of the EU of £17 billion. And the trading relationship is more inter-related than even these figures suggest. Our exporters rely on inputs from EU companies more than firms from anywhere else: 9% of the ‘value added’ of UK exports comes from inputs from within the EU, compared to 2.7% from the United States and 1.3% from China.

So the single market accounts for a huge volume of our trade, but if it is completed - so there are genuinely open markets for all services, the digital economy, energy and finance - we would see a dramatic increase in economic growth, for Britain and the rest of Europe. The Capital Markets Union - initiated and led by Britain - will allow finance to flow freely between member states: the first proposal alone could lead to £110 billion in extra lending to businesses. A completed energy single market could save up to £50 billion per year across the EU by 2030. And a digital single market is estimated to be worth up to £330 billion a year to the European economy overall. As Britain is the leading country in Europe when it comes to the digital economy, that is an enormous opportunity for us all.

These changes will mean greater economic growth in Britain, higher wages in Britain and lower prices for consumers - in Britain

responses.body:
I have some sympathy with your view. The hard bit in this election is interpreting the polls.

Most of the raw data has the tories with a small, narrowing, lead over labour. The published results emerge when the pollsters put the raw data through their models based on who they think will actually vote. Generally older people vote more than younger people. However this time the proportion of younger people saying they will vote is much higher than in the past. No one will know until next Thursday if this is true or not.

So the differences in poll ratings from the likes of icm and you gov is often down to how. Much credence they out on younger voters actually turning out in the numbers of they say they will.
